Bug.Summery: NullPointerException when doing a CVS update (in package explorer not through navigator??)
Bug.WithStack:
I get this stacktrace when i do an update:
!MESSAGE An internal error occurred during: "CVS Update". !STACK 0 java.lang.NullPointerException at org.eclipse.team.ui.operations.ResourceMappingOperation.getMerger(ResourceMappingOperation.java:158) at org.eclipse.team.ui.operations.ResourceMappingMergeOperation.performAutoMerge(ResourceMappingMergeOperation.java:218) at org.eclipse.team.ui.operations.ResourceMappingMergeOperation.performMerge(ResourceMappingMergeOperation.java:193) at org.eclipse.team.ui.operations.ResourceMappingMergeOperation.execute(ResourceMappingMergeOperation.java:123) at org.eclipse.team.ui.operations.ResourceMappingMergeOperation.execute(ResourceMappingMergeOperation.java:108) at org.eclipse.team.ui.operations.ResourceMappingOperation.run(ResourceMappingOperation.java:89) at org.eclipse.team.internal.ui.actions.JobRunnableContext.run(JobRunnableContext.java:146) at org.eclipse.team.internal.ui.actions.JobRunnableContext$ResourceJob.runInWorkspace(JobRunnableContext.java:72) at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.InternalWorkspaceJob.run(InternalWorkspaceJob.java:38) at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:58)
in build: I20051122-1300 The cause of this should be fixed in I20051123-1200. I'll leave this bug open as a reminder to protect against this in the ResourceMappingMergeOperation. Added appropriate null checks Verified

in build: I20051122-1300 The cause of this should be fixed in I20051123-1200. I'll leave this bug open as a reminder to protect against this in the ResourceMappingMergeOperation. Added appropriate null checks Verified

Bug.Summery: File search fails
Bug.WithStack:
When performing File Search get this error message for multiple files and the search is incomplete as a result:
Problems encountered during text search. File 'xxx/yyy/zzz.h' has been skipped, problem while reading: ('Resource is out of sync with the file system: /xxx/yyy/zzz.h.'). Resource is out of sync with the file system: /xxx/yyy/zzz.h. ... many more messages The workaround is to check Preferences/General/Workspace/Refresh automatically (default is off).
HOWEVER, this is still a bug b/c files listed in the error message were NOT changed.
ALSO, this is the most basic feature the first time user is likely to try. Getting these errors out of the blue (without ever changing files) looks very bad. At least the option "Refresh automatically" should be mentioned in the error message.
I'm not sure this is a CDT bug though; most likely Platform Core. Can you please redirect as necessary You're right this isn't a CDT bug since the CDT does not provide file search. I don't know where to redirect it so I'll leave that to you.
Bug.WithOutStack:
When performing File Search get this error message for multiple files and the search is incomplete as a result:
Problems encountered during text search. File 'xxx/yyy/zzz.h' has been skipped, problem while reading: ('Resource is out of sync with the file system: /xxx/yyy/zzz.h.'). Resource is out of sync with the file system: /xxx/yyy/zzz.h. ... many more messages The workaround is to check Preferences/General/Workspace/Refresh automatically (default is off).
HOWEVER, this is still a bug b/c files listed in the error message were NOT changed.
ALSO, this is the most basic feature the first time user is likely to try. Getting these errors out of the blue (without ever changing files) looks very bad. At least the option "Refresh automatically" should be mentioned in the error message.
I'm not sure this is a CDT bug though; most likely Platform Core. Can you please redirect as necessary You're right this isn't a CDT bug since the CDT does not provide file search. I don't know where to redirect it so I'll leave that to you.

Bug.Summery: How do i save a text file (html or xml) in UTF-8 encoding?

Lines.Line: 1. download Eclipse SDK
2. start with fresh workspace
3. create simple project 'P'
4. create file 'works.txt'
5. change encoding to UTF-8
6. write €
7. save
8. close
9. open

Bug.WithStack:
What ever i do in build I20051122-1300 i can't generate a html or xml file that is in utf-8 encoding to really save it also in utf-8.
For example i make a text file with this content: in the properties of the file i set the encoding to UTF-8 and i make the content this:
<html> €€€ </html>
but it will not save this file as UTF-8 the euro signs are always 0x80
johan Works for me using I20051122-1300 on WinXP with these steps: 1. download Eclipse SDK 2. start with fresh workspace 3. create simple project 'P' 4. create file 'works.txt' 5. change encoding to UTF-8 6. write € 7. save 8. close 9. open ==> €
see also: http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-text-home/development/bug-incomplete.htm
Bug.WithOutStack:
What ever i do in build I20051122-1300 i can't generate a html or xml file that is in utf-8 encoding to really save it also in utf-8.
For example i make a text file with this content: in the properties of the file i set the encoding to UTF-8 and i make the content this:
<html> €€€ </html>
but it will not save this file as UTF-8 the euro signs are always 0x80
johan Works for me using I20051122-1300 on WinXP with these steps: 1. download Eclipse SDK 2. start with fresh workspace 3. create simple project 'P' 4. create file 'works.txt' 5. change encoding to UTF-8 6. write € 7. save 8. close 9. open ==> €
see also: http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-text-home/development/bug-incomplete.htm

Bug.Summery: [compiler] Compiler tries to match non-accessible methods leading to compile errors

Lines.Line: 1.) Create a plug-in C, with a class c.C
2.) Create a plug-in B, which depends on C (but does not export that dependency).
3.) Create a class b.B in B with two methods:
public void method(String)
private void method(C)
4.) Create a plug-in A, which depends on B.
5.) Create a class a.A in A with a main method that creates an instance of B, and then calls B.method((String) null).
(1) Changed the visibility of the classes
(2) Removed classpath as a factor
(3) Changed the method signatures
1) the language spec is inconsistent: both interpretations are valid
2) the spec agrees with us
3) the spec agrees with Sun
... or are we talking about some interaction between our plug-in support and the compiler, or...?

Bug.WithStack:
I20051122-1200
There is discrepancy between how Sun's java compiler works, and how the Eclipse compiler works. The difference is in how method resolution is done while linking.
To reproduce, do the following: 1.) Create a plug-in C, with a class c.C 2.) Create a plug-in B, which depends on C (but does not export that dependency). 3.) Create a class b.B in B with two methods: public void method(String) private void method(C) 4.) Create a plug-in A, which depends on B. 5.) Create a class a.A in A with a main method that creates an instance of B, and then calls B.method((String) null).
Two compiler errors occur: Error The project was not built since its build path is incomplete. Cannot find the class file for c.C. Fix the build path then try building this project Error The type c.C cannot be resolved. It is indirectly referenced from required .class files
Workarounds: + Rename the private method. + Make B's dependency on C exported. + Make A dependent on C. Created attachment 30509 Zip file containing three plug-ins Created attachment 30510 Build script for Sun's compiler
This is a short script showing that Java's compiler works in this case
unzip example.zip sh build.sh May want to backport to 3.1 if proven to be wrong. Here is a much simpler testcase that shows we behave the same as javac:
Define the 3 types below and compile them with javac, then delete A.java & A.class and recompile C.java.
javac will report that it cannot find A.class when accessing the .class file B.class:
"C.java:3: cannot access A file A.class not found new B().method((String) null); ^ 1 error"
=======================================================
class A {} class B { public void method(String s) {} private void method(A a) {} } class C { void test() { new B().method((String) null); } } Then why does my example work on the Sun compiler but not in Eclipse? Showing your own example that does not contain the flaw is a rather strange form of rhetoric.
Doug says 'When I do X, an error appears in compiler A but not in compiler B' Kent says 'When I do Y, an error appears in both compiler A and compiler B'
How does Y have any bearing on X?
I feel there is clearly a discrepancy between the Java compiler and the Eclipse compilation process. I work on the user interface team, and have neither the expertise nor the time to figure out where this discrepancy lies: in the classpath computation, in Eclipse's compiler's handling of the classpath, or in the handling of visibility of Eclipse's compiler.
Notice that you have: (1) Changed the visibility of the classes (2) Removed classpath as a factor (3) Changed the method signatures
Since you don't seem inclined to put any effort into this, here is a counter-example to your counter-example.
class A {} class B { public void method(String s) {} private void method(A a) {} } class C { public void test() { new B().method(null); } } Why we should waste time trying to decipher your example?
I've provided you with the simple case and it shows we behave the same as javac. Kent - I am puzzled. I tried what is suggested in comment 2, and it seems javac is indeed tolerating the case. Did I miss something ?
D:\117804\c\src>javac -verbose c/C.java [parsing started c/C.java] [parsing completed 70ms] [search path for source files: [.]] [search path for class files: [D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\rt.jar, D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\jsse.jar, D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\jce.jar, D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\ch arsets.jar, D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\ext\dnsns.jar, D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\ext\localedata.jar, D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\ext\sunjce_provider.jar, D:\JDK1. 5.0\jre\lib\ext\sunpkcs11.jar, .]] [loading D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\rt.jar(java/lang/Object.class)] [checking c.C] [wrote c\C.class] [total 2493ms]
D:\117804\c\src>cd ..\..\b\src
D:\117804\b\src>javac -classpath ..\..\c\src b\B.java -verbose [parsing started b\B.java] [parsing completed 51ms] [search path for source files: [..\..\c\src]] [search path for class files: [D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\rt.jar, D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\jsse.jar, D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\jce.jar, D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\ch arsets.jar, D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\ext\dnsns.jar, D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\ext\localedata.jar, D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\ext\sunjce_provider.jar, D:\JDK1. 5.0\jre\lib\ext\sunpkcs11.jar, ..\..\c\src]] [loading ..\..\c\src\c\C.class] [loading D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\rt.jar(java/lang/Object.class)] [loading D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\rt.jar(java/lang/String.class)] [checking b.B] [wrote b\B.class] [total 331ms]
D:\117804\b\src>cd ..\..\a\src
D:\117804\a\src>javac -classpath ..\..\b\src a\A.java -verbose [parsing started a\A.java] [parsing completed 50ms] [search path for source files: [..\..\b\src]] [search path for class files: [D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\rt.jar, D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\jsse.jar, D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\jce.jar, D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\ch arsets.jar, D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\ext\dnsns.jar, D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\ext\localedata.jar, D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\ext\sunjce_provider.jar, D:\JDK1. 5.0\jre\lib\ext\sunpkcs11.jar, ..\..\b\src]] [loading ..\..\b\src\b\B.class] [loading D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\rt.jar(java/lang/Object.class)] [loading D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\rt.jar(java/lang/String.class)] [checking a.A] [wrote a\A.class] [total 330ms] The difference is whether you specify the cast to (String) in A.java. If no cast is used, then null is somewhat permissive. If (String) is passed, then I am getting an error with javac as well.
D:\117804\a\src>javac -classpath ..\..\b\src a\A.java -verbose [parsing started a\A.java] [parsing completed 50ms] [search path for source files: [..\..\b\src]] [search path for class files: [D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\rt.jar, D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\jsse.jar, D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\jce.jar, D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\ch arsets.jar, D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\ext\dnsns.jar, D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\ext\localedata.jar, D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\ext\sunjce_provider.jar, D:\JDK1. 5.0\jre\lib\ext\sunpkcs11.jar, ..\..\b\src]] [loading ..\..\b\src\b\B.class] [loading D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\rt.jar(java/lang/Object.class)] [loading D:\JDK1.5.0\jre\lib\rt.jar(java/lang/String.class)] [checking a.A] a\A.java:8: cannot access c.C file c\C.class not found b.method((String)null); ^ [total 330ms] 1 error And step 5 from the first comment is B.method((String) null):
"5.) Create a class a.A in A with a main method that creates an instance of B, and then calls B.method((String) null)."
Not B.method(null)
But I guess that is just more 'rhetoric' on my part for actually reading the steps to reproduce.
And somehow it must be the Eclipse compiler that is inconsistent, even when this example shows javac produces the same error:
class A {} class B { public void method(String s) {} public void method(A a) {} } class C { public void test() { new B().method(null); } }
When B is compiled, then A.class is removed, compiling C produces:
C.java:2: cannot access A file A.class not found public void test() { new B().method(null); } ^ 1 error
So why should we waste more time trying to support an obvious inconsistency? re: " The difference is whether you specify the cast to (String) in A.java. If no cast is used, then null is somewhat permissive. If (String) is passed, then I am getting an error with javac as well. " Just so I'm clear on this, are we saying that it's one of these three situations... 1) the language spec is inconsistent: both interpretations are valid 2) the spec agrees with us 3) the spec agrees with Sun ... or are we talking about some interaction between our plug-in support and the compiler, or...?

Bug.Summery: [WorkingSets] Not easy to switch between no working set and a window working set.
Bug.WithStack:
In the dropdown of for example package explorer where you can choose a working set there is a list of working sets that you previosly did choose.
But there is not quick entry to choose a window working set, it would be nice to have there. I use window working sets every where now. But sometimes i quickly have to see everything and then go back. But to go back to a window working set you need to go through the dialog. This shouldn't be needed.
Bug.WithOutStack:

But there is not quick entry to choose a window working set, it would be nice to have there. I use window working sets every where now. But sometimes i quickly have to see everything and then go back. But to go back to a window working set you need to go through the dialog. This shouldn't be needed.

Bug.Summery: File dialog missing text field on Fedora Core 4
Bug.WithStack:
On Fedora Core 4, choosing File->Open File... brings up a file dialog that is missing the text entry field. For those users whose systems rely on automounting that means our RCP app doesn't allow the user any way to navigate into directories that have not yet been automounted, making this problem a showstopper. This is the standard GTK+ file chooser dialog, however it is a common complaint. The fix is to use Ctrl-L to bring up a text entry. The following GNOME bug is tracking this issue, which will likely be fixed by having a button to toggle the pathbar between a text entry and the button view:
http://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=136541 As this is the standard platform dialog and there is an upstream bug, I am marking this WONTFIX for now (really, to be fixed upstream). Sorry about the "noise". I tried several different apps on the users' FC4 machine and the none of them actually used the GTK platform dialog, but there were a couple that looked the same so I had assumed that that was the platform dialog and it didn't have any issue.
And I had so diligently searched the Eclipse newsgroups and Eclipse bugzilla before filing the report... It's no trouble to reply to bugs, please don't ever feel afraid to file them. Which other apps did you try? Some GTK+ apps may be using the old (deprecated) GtkFileSelector dialog which did have a text entry. Umm, Mozilla, nedit, and a couple in-house apps, one of which had the same dialog as nedit. I just looked again and it looks like motif.
Thanks for the amazingly quick feedback. I've been pushing RCP here, and I find myself regularly boasting about how good responses are from the Eclipse team. Now if only I could be as good from my end - after months I still owe responses on two outstanding SWT "bugs", but I'm being overworked here... *** Bug 118473 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Since others are reporting this too, it's worth clarifying that you don't even need to type Ctrl-L - just start typing. It's pretty smart, too: autocompleting names once you've typed enough characters to uniquely identify a file or directory.
The only drawback is that if you copy a whole path from elsewhere, you do have to type Ctrl-L before Ctrl-V.

Umm, Mozilla, nedit, and a couple in-house apps, one of which had the same dialog as nedit. I just looked again and it looks like motif.
Thanks for the amazingly quick feedback. I've been pushing RCP here, and I find myself regularly boasting about how good responses are from the Eclipse team. Now if only I could be as good from my end - after months I still owe responses on two outstanding SWT "bugs", but I'm being overworked here... *** Bug 118473 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Since others are reporting this too, it's worth clarifying that you don't even need to type Ctrl-L - just start typing. It's pretty smart, too: autocompleting names once you've typed enough characters to uniquely identify a file or directory.
The only drawback is that if you copy a whole path from elsewhere, you do have to type Ctrl-L before Ctrl-V.

Bug.Summery: [Webdoc] (releasenotes) Collecting object references while profiling an 'enabled' mode application on z/OS gives a warning
Bug.WithStack:
An error popup occurs on the first "Collect Object References" operation while profiling an 'enabled' mode application on zOS using both the memory analysis and execution analysis types of profiling. The popup is labelled with an IWAT0003E messaage (Launch Java Processor Error) and contains an IWAT0004W message that specifies the reason to be "Heap dump failed because bad data passed from JVM".
After clearing the popup, a second (and any subsequent) collect object references operation will succeed. This information should be removed from the README once bug 117570 is fixed - Sending this updated readme item to Ruth Lee for review and check-in. This is item 1.5.9 in the 41 release notes - http://eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/releasenotes/releasenotes4_1_0.html.
Closed: Verified in release notes on website.

An error popup occurs on the first "Collect Object References" operation while profiling an 'enabled' mode application on zOS using both the memory analysis and execution analysis types of profiling. Bug.Summery: Add namespace and path properties on lib.

Lines.Line: - Firstly i am not sure what DE change is needed for this.
- THe DE should already providing public API to access the librarypath and the namespace for all the included libraries in a report desing.
- A report design can include multiple libraries
- when a user selects the libary node in the outline view, the property editor should should show the librarypath ( including name) and the name space.
- Note the above 2 proeprties should be read only and not allow user to modify.

Bug.WithStack:
Due Rima's requirement, we need shot namespace and path properties on lib node. But we don't find this properties on lib in properties view. Please add those properties. The library namespace is related to the design which includes it. That does not mean anything to the library itself. If we add the namespace as a property for the library, the namespace will be written out in the library design file. That is very strange. Next time, when the library is opened by another design, the namespace is changed.So I think library does not need the namespace property. We save the namespace with the corresponding library in the report design which includes the library. And the reason that the path should not be the property of library is it is computed by the design when you open the library.
I don't think the namespace & path should be displayed in the proeprty sheet.UI can add the namespace & path in the library editor view because we have the getNamespace() & getFileName() on the ModuleHandle(). If they're not property, they should not show on property editor also. Property editor only show properties. - Firstly i am not sure what DE change is needed for this. - THe DE should already providing public API to access the librarypath and the namespace for all the included libraries in a report desing.
UI behavior. - A report design can include multiple libraries - when a user selects the libary node in the outline view, the property editor should should show the librarypath ( including name) and the name space. - Note the above 2 proeprties should be read only and not allow user to modify.
That namespace and path are not properties of LibHandle. We can't show a non property in property editor. - UI code should really not be so restrictive. DE provides methods to access the namespace Libraryhandle.getnamespace, libraryHandle.getFileName() , please use these to show in proeprty editor.
- we dont need to support multi selection for this node.
Don't need that two value become properties. Cancel this requirement
Bug.WithOutStack:
Due Rima's requirement, we need shot namespace and path properties on lib node. But we don't find this properties on lib in properties view. Please add those properties. The library namespace is related to the design which includes it. That does not mean anything to the library itself. If we add the namespace as a property for the library, the namespace will be written out in the library design file. That is very strange. Next time, when the library is opened by another design, the namespace is changed.So I think library does not need the namespace property. We save the namespace with the corresponding library in the report design which includes the library. And the reason that the path should not be the property of library is it is computed by the design when you open the library.
I don't think the namespace & path should be displayed in the proeprty sheet.UI can add the namespace & path in the library editor view because we have the getNamespace() & getFileName() on the ModuleHandle(). If they're not property, they should not show on property editor also. Property editor only show properties. - Firstly i am not sure what DE change is needed for this. - THe DE should already providing public API to access the librarypath and the namespace for all the included libraries in a report desing.
UI behavior. - A report design can include multiple libraries - when a user selects the libary node in the outline view, the property editor should should show the librarypath ( including name) and the name space. - Note the above 2 proeprties should be read only and not allow user to modify.
That namespace and path are not properties of LibHandle. We can't show a non property in property editor. - UI code should really not be so restrictive. DE provides methods to access the namespace Libraryhandle.getnamespace, libraryHandle.getFileName() , please use these to show in proeprty editor.
- we dont need to support multi selection for this node.
Don't need that two value become properties. Cancel this requirement

Bug.Summery: [implementation] org.eclipse.core.filebuffers.FileBuffers#normalizeLocation returns inconsistent normalized path

Lines.Line: 1) Existing Workspace Files:
For a path or location for which there exists a workspace file, the
normalized form is that file's workspace relative, absolute path as
returned by IFile#getFullPath()
2) Non-existing Workspace Files:
For a path to a non-existing workspace file, the normalized form is the
absolute form of the path i.e. path.makeAbsolute()
3) External Files:
For a location for which there exists no workspace file, the normalized
form is the absolute form of the location i.e. location.makeAbsolute()

Bug.WithStack: org.eclipse.core.filebuffers.FileBuffers#normalizeLocation returns different normalized IPath. Here is the detail. Given that the workspace location is "C:\workspace", and there are no files. Then, when we run the follwoing code, IPath path1 = new Path("C:/workspace/nonexistingfile"); IFile file = ResourcesPlugin.getWorkspace().getRoot().getFileForLocation(path1); IPath path2 = FileBuffers.normalizeLocation(file.getLocation()); IPath path3 = FileBuffers.normalizeLocation(file.getFullPath()); path2.toString() is "C:/workspace/nonexistingfile", whereas path3.toString() is "/nonexistingfile". The key is that if path1 points to the existing file, both cases return the same normalized path ("/existingfile") as its java doc says, yet if path1 points to the non-existing file, they are different. According to its java doc, For a path to a non-existing workspace file, the normalized form is the absolute form of the path. and I guess this differenece comes from IPath#makeAbsolute's behaviour. I really don't know this difference is what is suppoed to be. Because some WTP components asuume that FileBuffers#normalizeLocation returns the consistent IPath if the passed IPath is semantically same. Good catch! The code listed in comment 0 results in an NPE since IWorkspaceRoot.getFileForLocation(IPath) returns 'null' if there's no file at the given location: * @return the corresponding file in the workspace, * or null if none Ah, the test case has a bug. Need a project. Both, the workspace and the project itself need to exist. Given that the workspace location is "C:\workspace", and the project location is "C:\workspace\project" and there are no files under this project, the revised test case is : IPath path1 = new Path("C:/workspace/project/nonexistingfile"); IFile file = ResourcesPlugin.getWorkspace().getRoot().getFileForLocation(path1); IPath path2 = FileBuffers.normalizeLocation(file.getLocation()); IPath path3 = FileBuffers.normalizeLocation(file.getFullPath()); path2.toString() is "C:/workspace/project/nonexistingfile", whereas path3.toString() is "/project/nonexistingfile". Note: According to IWorkspaceRoot#getFileForLocation java doc, it says : * The resulting file need not exist in the workspace. Actually, it works with 3.2M6. The current behavior is correct and according to the spech which says: 1) Existing Workspace Files: For a path or location for which there exists a workspace file, the normalized form is that file's workspace relative, absolute path as returned by IFile#getFullPath() 2) Non-existing Workspace Files: For a path to a non-existing workspace file, the normalized form is the absolute form of the path i.e. path.makeAbsolute() 3) External Files: For a location for which there exists no workspace file, the normalized form is the absolute form of the location i.e. location.makeAbsolute() In your example IPath path2 = FileBuffers.normalizeLocation(file.getLocation()); you enter a location and not a path and hence 3) is applied While here IPath path3 = FileBuffers.normalizeLocation(file.getFullPath()); you enter a path and hence 2) applies. IPath path3 = FileBuffers.normalizeLocation(file.getFullPath()); David, what would you think ? If that spec is right, I would guess some WTP usage would have a problem.... . I bet that WTP and many other clients would have by far more problems when we changed the contract after three years. The binding part of the API is the spec and not the implementation. The main problem/confusion is caused by combining path and location into one parameter, see bug 99610 for a way to improve this on our side. (In reply to comment #5) > David, what would you think ? If that spec is right, I would guess > some WTP usage would have a problem.... > I believe we have already worked about this unusual spec in WTP. :) And, I agree, as long as it is spec'd that way, it should not be changed, ... just "added to", or an alternative provided ... as Dani is going to do in bug 99610. If you still see a problem in WTP related to this, let us know.
Bug.WithOutStack: org.eclipse.core.filebuffers.FileBuffers#normalizeLocation returns different normalized IPath. Here is the detail. Given that the workspace location is "C:\workspace", and there are no files. Then, when we run the follwoing code, IPath path1 = new Path("C:/workspace/nonexistingfile"); IFile file = ResourcesPlugin.getWorkspace().getRoot().getFileForLocation(path1); IPath path2 = FileBuffers.normalizeLocation(file.getLocation()); IPath path3 = FileBuffers.normalizeLocation(file.getFullPath()); path2.toString() is "C:/workspace/nonexistingfile", whereas path3.toString() is "/nonexistingfile". The key is that if path1 points to the existing file, both cases return the same normalized path ("/existingfile") as its java doc says, yet if path1 points to the non-existing file, they are different. According to its java doc, For a path to a non-existing workspace file, the normalized form is the absolute form of the path. and I guess this differenece comes from IPath#makeAbsolute's behaviour. I really don't know this difference is what is suppoed to be. Because some WTP components asuume that FileBuffers#normalizeLocation returns the consistent IPath if the passed IPath is semantically same. Good catch! The code listed in comment 0 results in an NPE since IWorkspaceRoot.getFileForLocation(IPath) returns 'null' if there's no file at the given location: * @return the corresponding file in the workspace, * or null if none Ah, the test case has a bug. Need a project. Both, the workspace and the project itself need to exist. Given that the workspace location is "C:\workspace", and the project location is "C:\workspace\project" and there are no files under this project, the revised test case is : IPath path1 = new Path("C:/workspace/project/nonexistingfile"); IFile file = ResourcesPlugin.getWorkspace().getRoot().getFileForLocation(path1); IPath path2 = FileBuffers.normalizeLocation(file.getLocation()); IPath path3 = FileBuffers.normalizeLocation(file.getFullPath()); path2.toString() is "C:/workspace/project/nonexistingfile", whereas path3.toString() is "/project/nonexistingfile". Note: According to IWorkspaceRoot#getFileForLocation java doc, it says : * The resulting file need not exist in the workspace. Actually, it works with 3.2M6. The current behavior is correct and according to the spech which says: 1) Existing Workspace Files: For a path or location for which there exists a workspace file, the normalized form is that file's workspace relative, absolute path as returned by IFile#getFullPath() 2) Non-existing Workspace Files: For a path to a non-existing workspace file, the normalized form is the absolute form of the path i.e. path.makeAbsolute() 3) External Files: For a location for which there exists no workspace file, the normalized form is the absolute form of the location i.e. location.makeAbsolute() In your example IPath path2 = FileBuffers.normalizeLocation(file.getLocation()); you enter a location and not a path and hence 3) is applied While here IPath path3 = FileBuffers.normalizeLocation(file.getFullPath()); you enter a path and hence 2) applies. IPath path3 = FileBuffers.normalizeLocation(file.getFullPath()); David, what would you think ? If that spec is right, I would guess some WTP usage would have a problem.... . I bet that WTP and many other clients would have by far more problems when we changed the contract after three years. The binding part of the API is the spec and not the implementation. The main problem/confusion is caused by combining path and location into one parameter, see bug 99610 for a way to improve this on our side. (In reply to comment #5) > David, what would you think ? If that spec is right, I would guess > some WTP usage would have a problem.... > I believe we have already worked about this unusual spec in WTP. :) And, I agree, as long as it is spec'd that way, it should not be changed, ... just "added to", or an alternative provided ... as Dani is going to do in bug 99610. If you still see a problem in WTP related to this, let us know.

Bug.Summery: problem loading a 2-level DTD model when utilizing the cache
Bug.WithStack: There's as subtle logical error in our DTD model that causes resolution to fail. Easy to fix. I'll also check in a JUnit for this use case. Fixed now. JUnits have been added for ensure validators and content model builders work properly for the XML->DTD->DTD use case. This bug was moved to 'closed' state, since it is so old and it is assumed really fixed and no longer useful or need further attention. Feel free to re-open, or open a new bug, if this semi-automatic processing was done in error.

Bug.Summery: Allow collectors to output results in a tabular format
Bug.WithStack: This is part of refactoring the usage table into a separate collector. Each collector could return a list of lists that can be put into a tabular format if desired. This could simplify the exportToCSV methods in many of the collectors. Fyi, I'm still in the process of making some changes, but they're localized to the MylarUsageAnalysisCollector. Committing now. Yup, I was just annoyed by the redundancy between my report and csv methods. But notably it would be awkward to convert my report format into the tabular format because it reports the numbers that go into the calculations (that end up as cells in the table). What's the status of this, do we still need additional formatting beyond the current CSV? Closing this for now as export to cvs seems to be operating fine and more substantial refactoring may be needed.

Bug.Summery: messages associated with red squiggles don't update properly

Lines.Line: 1) select New->Examples->"Editing and validating XML"
2) open the file GolfCountryClub.xml
3) flip to the source view
4) under the existing <GolfCourse> elements, create a new one <GolfCourse> using content assist
5) notice the GolfCourse is red squiggled with a message like this "One of {Name} is expected"
6) validate and you'll see that the same error message is displayed in the problems view
----- ok so far so good... there's no problem yet -----
7) use content assist to add a <Name> to the new <GolfCourse>
8) notice that the red squiggle's message is still "One of {Name} is expected" -- this is wrong, the message should now be "One of {Yardage} is expected"
9) validate and you'll see the expect message does appear in the problems view

Bug.WithStack:
Here's how to reproduce this problem...
1) select New->Examples->"Editing and validating XML" 2) open the file GolfCountryClub.xml 3) flip to the source view 4) under the existing <GolfCourse> elements, create a new one <GolfCourse> using content assist 5) notice the GolfCourse is red squiggled with a message like this "One of {Name} is expected" 6) validate and you'll see that the same error message is displayed in the problems view
----- ok so far so good... there's no problem yet -----
7) use content assist to add a <Name> to the new <GolfCourse> 8) notice that the red squiggle's message is still "One of {Name} is expected" -- this is wrong, the message should now be "One of {Yardage} is expected" 9) validate and you'll see the expect message does appear in the problems view
So I'm going to guess that the logic for updating the message associated with the red squiggle has a bug in it. Mass transfer from pa to dw. Needs more triage.

Bug.Summery: Predefined table header, table footer and table detail styles don't work when previewed.

Lines.Line: 1. Add a predefined table header style.
2. Create a table and bind it to a data set, edit it.
3. Preview it and find that predefined table header style doesn't work.
ROM defines the styles of report elment in several ways:
1) the styles setted by the script
2) the styles setted by the highlight
3) the styles defined in the element itself.
4) the styles define in the named style which is used by the element
5) system predefined style such as table, table-header etc.
6) styles inherit from the container
7) system default styles
1) the styles setted by the script
2) the styles setted by the highlight
3) the styles defined in the element itself.
4) the styles define in the named style which is used by the element
5) system predefined style such as table, table-header etc.
6) styles inherit from the container
7) system default styles
1) inline style, include the script style, highlight style.
2) static style, inlcude the 3,4,5.
3) cascading style
4) system default

Bug.WithStack:
Description: Predefined table header, table footer and table detail styles don't work when previewed.
Steps to reproduce: 1. Add a predefined table header style. 2. Create a table and bind it to a data set, edit it. 3. Preview it and find that predefined table header style doesn't work. ROM defines the styles of report elment in several ways: 1) the styles setted by the script 2) the styles setted by the highlight 3) the styles defined in the element itself. 4) the styles define in the named style which is used by the element 5) system predefined style such as table, table-header etc. 6) styles inherit from the container 7) system default styles
To speed up the style process in engine, engine divide those styles into 4 catalogs: 1) inline style, include the script style, highlight style. 2) static style, inlcude the 3,4,5. 3) cascading style 4) system default
To get the static style, ENGINE use FactoryHandle to flatten the static style. It is correct for other elements except for table-header, table-footer and table-detail. The table-header, table-footer and table-detail are not report item themselves and not the container of the inner rows. That means the table-header, table-footer and table-detail's style can't be handle through cascading as they are not container.
That requires the FactoryHandle to handle this case properly. The table-header, table-footer and table-details define the rows style in the header, footer and detail instead of the footer ,header and detail themselves.
MODEL should update the FactoryHanle searching algorithm to include table-header,footer and table-detail styles for inner rows. *** Bug 117975 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Fixed.
Take container/slot selector search into consideration in factory property search. Verified in build 20051125.
Bug.WithOutStack:
Description: Predefined table header, table footer and table detail styles don't work when previewed.
Steps to reproduce: 1. Add a predefined table header style. 2. Create a table and bind it to a data set, edit it. 3. Preview it and find that predefined table header style doesn't work. ROM defines the styles of report elment in several ways: 1) the styles setted by the script 2) the styles setted by the highlight 3) the styles defined in the element itself. 4) the styles define in the named style which is used by the element 5) system predefined style such as table, table-header etc. 6) styles inherit from the container 7) system default styles
To speed up the style process in engine, engine divide those styles into 4 catalogs: 1) inline style, include the script style, highlight style. 2) static style, inlcude the 3,4,5. 3) cascading style 4) system default
To get the static style, ENGINE use FactoryHandle to flatten the static style. It is correct for other elements except for table-header, table-footer and table-detail. The table-header, table-footer and table-detail are not report item themselves and not the container of the inner rows. That means the table-header, table-footer and table-detail's style can't be handle through cascading as they are not container.
That requires the FactoryHandle to handle this case properly. The table-header, table-footer and table-details define the rows style in the header, footer and detail instead of the footer ,header and detail themselves.
MODEL should update the FactoryHanle searching algorithm to include table-header,footer and table-detail styles for inner rows. *** Bug 117975 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Fixed.
Take container/slot selector search into consideration in factory property search. Verified in build 20051125.

Bug.Summery: [EditorMgmt] [Perspectives] Editor content area should be closed and removed when all files are closed

source_code.code: IServiceLocator sl = ... partSite or window or workbench;

Bug.WithStack:
I started using TPTP on 3.1.1 and noticed that the Profiling perspective does not have an "Editor content area" i.e. the panel where each newly opened file comes and sits in a tab - refered to as "Editor Panel" henceforth here.
This was new to me in Eclipse because minimizing the "Editor Panel" makes it sit awkwardly in a corner disrupting the flow of the screen.
I also noticed that if you open a new file in the Profiling perspective or do a Window/New Editor the "Editor Panel" gets created.
And, if you reset the Profiling perspective it removes the "Editor Panel". This is wonderful.
So, if we have this capability why not just remove the "Editor Panel" when all files are closed ? We only use the Java and Java Browsing to open files. But once a file is opened in some other perspective the only way to get rid of the "Editor Panel" is to reset it and lose your customisation.
What do you guys think ?
PS: I also noticed in 3.2M3 resetting the Profiling Perspective does not remove the "Editor Panel" is this a feature we lost in 3.2 ? - Bug ? Paul: I think this is more your kind of stuff. If I've judged wrong, please feel free to bounce it back to me. I agree with this. The editor area should not be so special, it should work like views. When you close all the views in a stack, the other workbench parts resize to fill the unused space. Editors should work the same way - when you close the last editor in a stack the other parts should resize to fill the space instead of leaving a big gray rectangle.
See also bug 94191 and bug 100428. I disagree. At least in the IDE case, closing all editors is a common occurrence, and removing the space completely would lead to too much UI instability.
Maybe, it's hard to say without trying it. But I have an RCP app where it would definitely be more usable for that reserved editor area to go away. See also bug 8886. Why not have a preference/setting that says whether the editor area should auto-hide or not? It could even be a part of the perspective. So instead of having setEditorAreaVisuble(true), you'd have setEditorAreaVisibleAllTheTime(true) instead. When a file is opened, the editor would show/hide if VisibleAllTheTime is false (for RCP apps) and always be preesent if VisibleAllTheTime is true (for IDEs). I think it is very much relevant and sensible to remove the content area from the perspective. I do not understand the "UI instability" comment (is this from a coding point of view ?).
For example; we use the TPTP perspective for profiling only and like to use the full IDE content area for TPTP views. Anyone who has used TPTP will appreciate this (with all the graphs and stats etc).
When we want to edit java code we switch to the Java perspective. If "jump to code" or similary action is selected from TPTP ( or any other perspective for that matter ) they should "switch" to the Java Perspective and display the Java file in the editor content area of that i.e. switched perspective.
Switching back to TPTP or the previous perspective should not display the editor content area. This is the KEY usability problem I am trying to address by raising this issue.
We would like to keep each perspective "objective".
*** Bug 144731 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** There are currently no plans to work on this feature.
PW
I vaguely remember that we had a menu item to explicitely hide the editor area at one point. Is that true? If so, does anyone have the background on why we removed it? (I suspect it was because users found it confusing.)
"The editor area should not be so special" is exactly the kind of question we are considering as part of the "Improve workbench usability." plan item (bug 154120). It seems odd that we aren't at least re-visiting whether we want this behavior or not. There was a menu item that was removed to free up space and because users might find it confusing. It is still available as a command that you can bind to, and run programmatically.
IServiceLocator sl = ... partSite or window or workbench; IHandlerService handlerService = (IHandlerService) sl.getService(IHandlerService.class); handlerService.executeCommand("org.eclipse.ui.window.hideShowEditors", null);
PW
Eric, what if we added an auto-hide option in the presentation where we check for empty containers?
PW
Hmmm, I thought I'd just commented on this but it seems to have been lost so I'll try again.
First, user settable options should become a -last resort-; we've taken the easy path far too often and ended up with waaaaay too many options. RCP configurable options are different; the complexity is only seen by product developers (who ge paid to manage the complexity...;-). If we -must 'optionize' this then the correct place to have it would be in the perspective -definition-, not as a user preference.
As part of the new minimize work there will be an 'editor stack' that will appear when the editor area is minimized (it'll no longer be as 'special'). This state is perspective based so it can be minimized in the TPTP perspective and not in the java perspective.
I'm with Nick that this would drive me nuts...I use "Close all Editors" all the time and certainly wouldn't want the area to go away (since the next thing I do, generally, is to open a new editor...;-).
But if you were working in a perspective that contained many views that could use the space, and opened editors there only occasionally, you *would* want the area to close again. To me this argues that it should be a perspective-specific setting.
Whatever gets done though, in 3.3 the hide editor area command better be equivalent to "minimize the editor stack" as Eric described, or we're idiots. For a related issue: Bug 18460 [WorkbenchParts] 'Hide editors' should deactivate active editor parts
PW
Is this planned for 3.3 ?
I hadn't planned on it. As various comments infer, this behavior istn't suitable for the workbench in general and a quick look at IWorkbenchPage implies that clients should be able to implement this behavior should they so desire.
You can add a property change listener on "CHANGE_EDITOR_CLOSE", use 'getEditorReferences()' to determine if there are any more open and 'setERditorAreaVisible(false)' to hide it (the inverse code to handle opening the first editor is left as an excercise to the reader).
Any state management issues resulting from this code would constitute workbench defect (i.e. they'd be 'my problem'...;-).
I'm marking as WONTFIX until somebody can shoot holes in the above approach...

Bug.Summery: No data available when preview a cascading parameter group

2.New a report and includes the library
3.Add a cascading parameter group in report and refer the library.dataset
4.Preview the report

Bug.WithStack:
Description: No data available when preview a cascading parameter group
Steps to reproduce: 1.New a library with data source and data set 2.New a report and includes the library 3.Add a cascading parameter group in report and refer the library.dataset 4.Preview the report
Expected result: All value available will be listed in the "Enter Parameters" dialog
Actual result: The value list is grayed out Need to change to explicitly use the data source data set in the report. Model resolved the dataSetbut the data of the dataSet should be returned by DtE or Engine. use qualified name in GetParamterDefinitionTask. Verified in build 20051125

Bug.Summery: FACET error can't fix from dialogue
Bug.WithStack:
sdk-20051122-2306 1.0M9 Tue, 22 Nov 2005 -- 23:06 (UTC)
I have a number of projects with the following facet config:
<faceted-project> <runtime name="Apache Tomcat v5.5"/> <fixed facet="jst.web"/> <fixed facet="jst.java"/> <installed facet="jst.web" version="2.4"/> <installed facet="jst.java" version="1.4"/> </faceted-project>
The errors I get are:
Java 1.4 cannot be uninstalled. Cannot install project facet Java 5.0. Some version of this project facet is already installed.
Then there is no way from the dialog to fix the problem, I can't change the Java version and I can't untick Java, when I click finish I get a contraint error.
BUT WHY IS IT A PROBLEM ANYWAY ?
Point 1) Now the only server runtimes I have a Tomcat 5.5 which as you know Tomcat itself has a dependancy on JDK5. But this does not mean the projects running under it have a dependancy on JDK5 also. Since JDK5 support backward compatible JDK1.4. I'm not sure this is related to the problem but the java version the runtime uses needs to be the same or _*HIGHER*_ than the one the project needs.
Point 2) My workspace default has 5.0 setup as the default compile output. This project inherits that default. I'm not sure if anyone has throught out that issue of what relationship the project facet should have to the Properties -> Compiler compliance level value.
Point 3) I have tested the problem out with 2 projects. One inherits my workspace default of 5.0 and another overrides and sets to 1.4 compliance level.
Both have the same problem, in that the facet is set to 1.4 but it still wants to force it to 5.
Which I regard: * an internal config error for my inherited compliance level of 5.0 (since facet should be _BROUGHT_UP_ to compile compliance level) * completely valid for the overridden one set to 1.4 (because 1.4 applications work under a Java5 server runtimes)
A Java1.4 project can be launched and run under Tomcat v5.5 this is valid. The only thing that _NEEDS_ Java5 is Tomcat v5.5 itself, the web application can be 1.4.
The workaround from the Java5 compliance level projects is to manually edit the facet XML config file for all my projects using Java5 to that level is correctly set to 5.
However there is still a problem / error with the facet dialog when I have a genuine 1.4 through and through project.
Point 4) Exactly what if the Java facet trying to describe ?
Its perfectly valid to develop a Servlet 2.3 app with 1.4 compiler compliance but use Tomcat v5.5 runtime in development (because other projects you work on use Servlet 2.4 and/or Java5), but export and deploy your project to Tomcat v5.0 (which supports of JDK1.4/Servlet2.3) on a production server.
Dupe bug #117377 ?
Dupe bug #117780 ?
Although marking it a dupe probably means no one will actually read what I've written.
The only question thats not clear is what does a "jst.java" facet really mean ?
This should all be fixed now. There were a few regressions that caused problems like being able to change the versions, but I believed they have all been addressed now.
BTW, jst.java facet version represents the version of the java language features available to that project (a.k.a. the compiler level). wtp-sdk-1.0M9.zip Wed, 30 Nov 2005 -- 07:33 (UTC)
The good points the dialog seems to behave well (no errors I can't get out of and fix now).
But because I am completely unsure what is right and what is wrong I really dont know if I should put a report in for this issue.
Is it correct that if I have Compiler Compliance level set to 1.4 that the facet is forced to be 5 with Apache Runtime v5.5 set ?
[Situation: Dynamic Web Module jst.web 2.4, jst.java 5, Tomcat v5.5 runtime, compiler compliance 1.4 !!!, dialog only allows jst.java=5 I cant set to anything else, if I untick Apache Tomcat v5.5 I can set the compiler compliance to 1.4, but the java language feature set my project supports is capped by the java language compilance level, even if the runtime I select just so happens to have Java5 support, to my project that does not matter since it never used any java5 features as its a 1.4 project which Tomcat 5.5 supports]
[Situation: J2EE Utility Project jst.utility 1.0, compiler compliance 1.4, facet dialog looks like it will allow setting of jst.java 5 (which feels wrong to me, since the compiler compliace level sets an upper cap on java language features)]
Minor UI feedback:
* The Add/Remove facet dialoge uses the whole horizonal desktop space, seems to dominate my desktoy.
* The Show Runtime button on Linux-GTK is about 12 to 22 pixels short in the X direction to see the "e" at the end of "<< Show Runtime" and the ">" at the end of "Hide Runtimes >>" no aount of resizing the window fixes is.
Reopened to get your attention, please close as you see fit.
It sounds like one of the necessary changes have not not been released yet if you are not able to pick 1.4 for jst.java while using Tomcat on 5.0 vm. Could you try again on the official RC1 build? Thanks.
Please open the ui feedback items as separate issues. 1.0RC1
I am able to pick 1.4 or 5.0 with Tomcat v5.5 selected.
My other query in the report was that I have compiler compliance set to 1.4 facet add/remove allows me to pick 5.0 from the facet, if I do that and Okay the dialogue.
When I look at the compiler compliance level is has been adjusted to 5.0 to match, but I was never offered any dialogue "Complier Settings Changed" to rebuild my project under the new compiler settings, like I would be if I manaully chnged the complier compliance and clicked apply.
Now if I try the reverse situation complier compliance=5.0 jst.java=5.0, then I go and downgrade the compiler compliance level to 1.4, I get the usual rebuild question dialogue. But if I look back at the jst.java facet its still 5.0.
I understand I'm not using 1.0RC1 declared build yet and will go back and re-test these findings with the declared build and reopen this bug at that time.
There is no prompting to rebuild after changing jst.java level. It's most likely too late for 1.0, but if you want to open a separate bug to track this issue we can make sure that its fixed in a later release.
Also, as you have noticed if you manualy change the compiler level in the properties page, the facet will not be updated. In fact, the change may not be legal (due to violating facet and runtime constraints). We will probably need to write a validator to detect this case. Again, probably for the next release. (In reply to comment #5) > 1.0RC1 > > I am able to pick 1.4 or 5.0 with Tomcat v5.5 selected.
I am using 1.0.1 and I never get the java 5 option. My default compliance level is 5.0 and yet every time I configure a J2EE runtime it gets pegged to a 1.4 JRE with no option that I can see to toggle it. Jacob,
When you configure your server runtime, you need to point at a 5.0 JVM. If your server runtime points to a 1.4 JVM, you will not be able to select 5.0 compliance level for your project.
Closing.

Bug.Summery: CTags indexer cannot process linked source folders

Lines.Line: 1. Instead of simply running ctags from the project root directory ctags must be called for all project source folders in a loop. ctags must be called with an absolute path which is valid in the machine's file system on which it is run.
Like this:
try {
2. Since we are now calling runCTags() in a loop we must add the -a option for ctags so that parse results will be appended.

3. We give ctags the (absolute) path of the directory to parse instead of just starting the process in the directory and letting ctags implicitly working from the current directory. This makes ctags write absolute file paths into the tags file too and so the files can surely be located.
- For resources which are actually in the file tree below the project ctags is started with the project dir as current dir and a relative path to the source folder.
- If no source folders are defined then the project dir is the default source folder.
- If a source folder is linked and lies outside the workspace tree then ctags gets the absolute path to the tree, starts indexing from there and creates tag entries with absolute paths.
- Mini project with project folder as default source folder.
- Mini project with mixed normal and linked source folders.
- Large project with linked source folders only.
- If a linked source folder lies outside the project but inside the workspace tree then the search does find the entries but trying to open an editor from there fails (needs further investigation).
- Not tested on Windows (Cygwin+ctags) - anybody out there who can do that?
- This won't help with general linked folders, only with source folders since we start at the source roots. So if you have a linked folder deeper down in the hierarchy ctags won't follow the link.

Bug.Summery: Some values are not stored after switchinng to the source page

Lines.Line: 1. Check out org.eclipse.help.ui from head.

4. Select 'subpage' in the left viewer

7. Go back to the 'Definition' page

9. Ctrl-S and close the editor.

fixed

org.eclipse.wst.sse.ui/plugin.xml provides some keybidings through the org.eclipse.ui.bindings extension. According to its spec,

Bug.Summery: LTW with Hibernate/CGLIB/ASM

Stacktrace.Reason: (class: com/mprv/secsph/profile/domain/UrlItem$$EnhancerByCGLIB$$859d1101, method: changeItemMode signature: (Lcom/mprv/secsph/profile/domain/ProfileItem$ItemStatus;Lcom/mprv/secsph/profile/domain/ProfileItem$StatusReason;Z)Z) Inconsistent stack height 2

source_code.code: // BANG, route to 85 that leaves us with the additional MethodInterceptor on the stack.

Lines.Line: 1. Added support for <weaver><dump within="com.*" beforeandafter="true"/> in aop.xml to allow dumping of generated proxies both before and after weaving
2. Moved dump() method into WeavingAdaptor
3. Added new dump tests
patches checked in.
Yes, I have an around advices.
I'll post the dumps right after the new DEV build will be available.
1. _ajdump - I intentionally left only the relevant packages (you know, we are a commercial company :-) ):
* com/mprv/secsph/profile/changes - contains compiled Aspects
* com/mprv/secsph/profile/domain - contains Hibernate's domain objects. Here Hibernate generates it's proxies at runtime.
* com/mprv/secsph/profiling/impl - contains code which is proxied by Spring - also at runtime
2. application.log - Log4J output - Here you will find the exceptions which we are trying to fix :) thrown by CGLib.
3. output.log - mostly weaver output (-showWeaveInfo -verbose)
1. The necessary one line change to World

2. Replacement of "resolved == ResolvedType.MISSING" with "resolved.isMissing()" and "unresolved == ResolvedType.MISSING" with "ResolvedType.isMissing(unresolved)". The existing public MISSING field should probably be removed to avoid use.
3. Two new dump testcases that rely on the changes.
Matthew,

1) Are you just redeploying an application as a war here? That shouldn't require AspectJ Hot Swap support. I just verified that there's no problem deploying a new version of an application to Tomcat 5.5.9: it redeploys without requiring hotswapping (it creates a new ClassLoader). Of course, if you are trying to run exploded classes or if you are redeploying shared library code, then that could be a problem. It often is still easier to reploy a jar than to restart the server...

2) Why can't AspectJ put after returning advice calls in front of each of the bytecode ireturn's instead of requiring a single return? Since multiple returns is valid bytecode, AspectJ should just support it. Right? Even if the CGLIB code is ugly, AspectJ's weaver ought to support verifiable bytecode.

3) I was going to report a bug I saw yesterday whereby I got a BCException in matching names like $Proxy4 in ResolvedType.getDeclaringType (since it tries to resolve a type with the name ""). Hopefully there is already revised logic that handles this case.

- All the VerifyError exceptions are caused CGLIB generated classes which have a name containing 2 consecutive $ symbols. Some fail with "Inconsistent stack height", others with "Illegal instruction".

- Unfortunately we do not have the dumped bytecode for any of the generated classes. This is possible because the "shouldDump()" method in ClassLoaderWeavingAdaptor tries to resolve the type whixh will of course fail. The matching logic needs to cope with generated code (including closures which cannot be dumped for a similar reason).

- There are a _lot_ of [Xlint:adviceDidNotMatch] messages, one for each piece of advice in each aspect that does not match the particular class being woven. This is highly likely in a large system using multiple (11) aspects. I think this warning should be automatically suppressed but overrideable for LTW.
Starting with com/mprv/secsph/profile/domain/UrlItem$$EnhancerByCGLIB$$b7f17874
- The failing method changeItemMode() is not actually
- There is a cflow counter for ChangeItemProtector
- There is neither a weavInfo nor info/Xlint for this aspect
General comments:
- The same aspects are registered a number of times suggesting there are multiple class loaders (applications)

- We probably need to run with "aj.weaving.verbose=true" to get messages before aop.xml parsing. Alternatively this could be "held" until verbose mode is know when they can be deleted or released to the console
- We should enhance the default message handler to append class loader name/identity and even a time stamp
- We need the before byte-code for the failing classes
- We should make matching on "*" simpler with no need to resolve types
Now looking at com/mprv/secsph/profile/domain/IpValue$$EnhancerByCGLIB$$4fe075c$$FastClassByCGLIB$$5f1ec221

According to the long discussion in the mailing list (http://dev.eclipse.org/mhonarc/lists/aspectj-dev/msg01869.html), I understand that the problem with AjAttribute should affect only AspectJ functionality, because someone who is "lower" in the stack (ASM or whatever) ignores those attributes on it's way.

Thanks! Can you tell me what the setup is? Are the CGLIB proxies generated offline i.e. do they exist before you start the system or are they generated online? Have you configured LTW using -javaagent? Can you post the aspect you are using?
Thanks The details are:
Hibernate 3.0.5 - CGLib and ASM libraries are those which bundled with this Hibernate version.
AspectJ - Dev. build from yesterday (Nov 23).
CGLIB proxies are generated online - they don't before the system starts. Take a look at Hibernate's CGLIBLazyInitializer class.
Yes, I've configured LTW using -javaagent option.
The aspect, I think, have to contain "method-execution" pointcat which refers to getters/setters in the domain objects which are mapped to DB with Hibernate. (I hope it was understandable sentence :-) ).
If you need something, I'm here. Thanks! I meant: " ... they don't exist ..." We are building a new version of AspectJ that will allow the dumping of selected byte-code both before and after weaving. Some fail with "Inconsistent stack height", others with "Illegal instruction". - Unfortunately we do not have the dumped bytecode for any of the generated classes. This is possible because the "shouldDump()" method in ClassLoaderWeavingAdaptor tries to resolve the type whixh will of course fail. The matching logic needs to cope with generated code (including closures which cannot be dumped for a similar reason). - There are a _lot_ of [Xlint:adviceDidNotMatch] messages, one for each piece of advice in each aspect that does not match the particular class being woven. This is highly likely in a large system using multiple (11) aspects. I think this warning should be automatically suppressed but overrideable for LTW. I'd like to see the 'before weaving' code for that case.
On the second case, I've fixed multiple bugs this release in the BCEL handling of switch statements. The instruction at 2566 suggests bcel has messed up how it manipulated the tableswitch:
2566: tableswitch{ //-845341380 to 1730110032 default: 2611 }
again it would be great to see the code 'before' weaving to see what this switch statement looked like. There are multiple formats for tableswitch and in particluar I think there is a special format when there is only a default entry or very few entries (if thats what this was in the original...). It doesn't matter that the switch isn't advised - the fact that the method is advised means bcel has cracked open the method and started tinkering with it.
get me the before bytecode !!! :) Created attachment 30873 New dump with generated classes in "_before"

In order to dump generated code using type patterns either before weaving proxies or after generating closures we need to be able to match on missing type names. World.resolveToReferenceType() is changed to return MissingResolvedTypeWithKnownSignature where possible. This patch includes: 1. The necessary one line change to World 2. Replacement of "resolved == ResolvedType.MISSING" with "resolved.isMissing()" and "unresolved == ResolvedType.MISSING" with "ResolvedType.isMissing(unresolved)". The existing public MISSING field should probably be removed to avoid use. 3. Two new dump testcases that rely on the changes. Matthew,

Hi,
I hope it'll be enough, if not, tell me. Here is the lookupswitch statement:
2566: lookupswitch{ //2 -845341380: 2592; 1730110032: 2604; default: 2615 }
And here is what happens to it after bcel has chewed on it:
2566: tableswitch{ //-845341380 to 1730110032 default: 2611 }
and then javap crashes.... If the BCEL verifier catches these 2 problems could we switch it on by default? It might even be useful in batch mode to identify problematic byte-code before it is executed. We could then allow the user to switch it off for performance reasons e.g. -Xnoverify (this used to be an option in early JDKs). The advantage of not waiting for the JVM to catch problems is that we have more context to help diagnose the problem. Also under LTW we could automatically dump before/after byte-code without asking the user to reproduce and even return the unwoven byte-code to the JVM so that the program can continue to load rather than failing. > If the BCEL verifier catches these 2 problems could we switch it on by default?
I would have have it *off* by default but it could be enabled through an option. It adds *significant* overhead, analysing every possible control flow through every single method in every single class.
Although it catches them, it is supremely unhelpful for diagnosing them - telling me very little that javap doesn't, but it provides something I can hack, unlike javap. I have fixed the damaged switch statement issue (manifests as 'invalid instruction'). The problem was BCEL - when we copy an instruction stream because we are weaving it, BCEL tries to be clever and use a tableswitch rather than a lookupswitch, which is a valid optimization in some circumstances. It can't cope with the ranges that are in the switch for this generated cglib stuff:
lookupswitch{ //2 -845341380: 2592; 1730110032: 2604; default: 2615 }
The optimization only works if the entries are numerically in order with no gaps (eg: 1,2,3,4) - the arithmetic bcel does determines that these two *obey* these rule (doh!) - so it transforms this into a completely broken tableswitch.
I've put a test in the suite (amazing I could reduce it to this ...)
public class BrokenSwitch { public static void main(String []argv) { int i = 1; switch (i) { case -845341380: System.err.println("a");break; case 1730110032: System.err.println("b");break; default: System.err.println("c");break; } } }
aspect X { before(): execution(* BrokenSwitch.main(..)) {} }
fix for this part of the problem will be in the next AJ dev build. That leaves the other (worse) problem of inconsistent stack height (unless this fix magically fixes the stack problem ... but thats unlikely) One down, one to go ... :-)

I believe it is a bug/feature of cglib. Something that would still allow the class to pass verification but mean the methods being advised aren't quite well formed - so that when AspectJ modifies them, the problem in the method is exposed.
I have a fix (*cough* hack) that involves me transforming the cglib code to correct some stack management in it before AspectJ modifies it.
I'm currently having a problem working out a stable fix - since I only need to do this extra manipulation when aspectj is weaving a method in a cglib generated class. Ok ... one of my famous long winded explanations .. fascinating stuff (well I think so) ... just call me a bytecode god ;)
We need to look at the code CGLIB creates first, here is an example method that is going to get woven by an aspect:

Basically it is choosing to delegate to a proxy for the method or call the original method. Important things to note:
Instruction 72: a return Instruction 80: a return
so there are two routes out of this method. This method verifies fine. The woven version that fails verification has actually been targetted by a cflow entry weave (indicating it matches the top of a cflow). This means the method is modified to increment a stack at the start and decrement a stack at the end:

This fails verification with an 'inconsistent stack error'. Asking my hacked BCEL verifier for more information I simply get told:
Cannot merge stacks of different size: OperandStack A: Slots used: 2 MaxStack: 9. int (Size: 1) net.sf.cglib.proxy.MethodInterceptor (Size: 1)
OperandStack B: Slots used: 1 MaxStack: 9. int (Size: 1) Execution flow: 0: getstatic 1772 [InstructionContext] 3: invokevirtual 1685 [InstructionContext] 6: aload_0 [InstructionContext] 7: getfield 38 [InstructionContext] 10: dup [InstructionContext] 11: ifnonnull -> 23 [InstructionContext] 23: dup [InstructionContext] 24: ifnull -> 81 [InstructionContext] 27: aload_0 [InstructionContext] 28: getstatic 648 [InstructionContext] 31: iconst_3 [InstructionContext] 32: anewarray 80 [InstructionContext] 35: dup [InstructionContext] 36: iconst_0 [InstructionContext] 37: aload_1 [InstructionContext] 38: aastore [InstructionContext] 39: dup [InstructionContext] 40: iconst_1 [InstructionContext] 41: aload_2 [InstructionContext] 42: aastore [InstructionContext] 43: dup [InstructionContext] 44: iconst_2 [InstructionContext] 45: iload_3 [InstructionContext] 46: new 308 [InstructionContext] 49: dup_x1 [InstructionContext] 50: swap [InstructionContext] 51: invokespecial 651 [InstructionContext] 54: aastore [InstructionContext] 55: getstatic 653 [InstructionContext] 58: invokeinterface 54 [InstructionContext] 63: dup [InstructionContext] 64: ifnonnull -> 72 [InstructionContext] 72: checkcast 308 [InstructionContext] 75: invokevirtual 312 [InstructionContext] 78: goto -> 102 [InstructionContext] 102: getstatic 1772 [InstructionContext]
What the hell does that mean? Basically it means there are 2 routes to instruction 102 in this method and when we arrive at instruction 102, these two routes have a different stack. In one route we only have an int (actually representing a boolean) on the stack. In route two we have the same int (representing a boolean) and a MethodInterceptor instance. Verification does not allow two routes to an instruction to have differing stacks.
Err ... so what the hell does that mean?
First, lets reduce the problem. The above woven code includes finally clauses and before advice - all messy and clouding the issue. Let's switch to just having 'after() returning' advice on the method. Here is another woven form of the code that also fails verification:
protected final boolean changeItemMode(com.mprv.secsph.profile.domain.ProfileItem$ItemStatus, com.mprv.secsph.profile.domain.ProfileItem$StatusReason, boolean); Code: Stack=9, Locals=4, Args_size=4 0: aload_0 1: getfield #38; //Field CGLIB$CALLBACK_0:Lnet/sf/cglib/proxy/MethodInterceptor; 4: dup 5: ifnonnull 17 8: pop 9: aload_0 10: invokestatic #42; //Method CGLIB$BIND_CALLBACKS:(Ljava/lang/Object;)V 13: aload_0 14: getfield #38; //Field CGLIB$CALLBACK_0:Lnet/sf/cglib/proxy/MethodInterceptor; 17: dup 18: ifnull 75 21: aload_0 22: getstatic #648; //Field CGLIB$changeItemMode$52$Method:Ljava/lang/reflect/Method; 25: iconst_3 26: anewarray #80; //class java/lang/Object 29: dup 30: iconst_0 31: aload_1 32: aastore 33: dup 34: iconst_1 35: aload_2 36: aastore 37: dup 38: iconst_2 39: iload_3 40: new #308; //class java/lang/Boolean 43: dup_x1 44: swap 45: invokespecial #651; //Method java/lang/Boolean."<init>":(Z)V 48: aastore 49: getstatic #653; //Field CGLIB$changeItemMode$52$Proxy:Lnet/sf/cglib/proxy/MethodProxy; 52: invokeinterface #54, 5; //InterfaceMethod net/sf/cglib/proxy/MethodInterceptor.intercept:(Ljava/lang/Object;Ljava/lang/reflect/Method;[Ljava/lang/Object;Lnet/sf/cglib/proxy/MethodProxy;)Ljava/lang/Object; 57: dup 58: ifnonnull 66 61: pop 62: iconst_0 63: goto 72 66: checkcast #308; //class java/lang/Boolean 69: invokevirtual #312; //Method java/lang/Boolean.booleanValue:()Z 72: goto 85 75: aload_0 76: aload_1 77: aload_2 78: iload_3 79: invokespecial #646; //Method com/mprv/secsph/profile/domain/BaseParameterItem.changeItemMode:(Lcom/mprv/secsph/profile/domain/ProfileItem$ItemStatus;Lcom/mprv/secsph/profile/domain/ProfileItem$StatusReason;Z)Z 82: goto 85 85: invokestatic #1656; //Method A.aspectOf:()LA; 88: invokevirtual #1659; //Method A.ajc$afterReturning$A$1$4c9f519a:()V 91: ireturn
So, we can see the afterReturning advice at the end of the bytecode. What's gone wrong? The verification failure is now:
Execution flow: 0: aload_0 [InstructionContext] 1: getfield 38 [InstructionContext] 4: dup [InstructionContext] 5: ifnonnull -> 17 [InstructionContext] 17: dup [InstructionContext] 18: ifnull -> 75 [InstructionContext] 21: aload_0 [InstructionContext] 22: getstatic 648 [InstructionContext] 25: iconst_3 [InstructionContext] 26: anewarray 80 [InstructionContext] 29: dup [InstructionContext] 30: iconst_0 [InstructionContext] 31: aload_1 [InstructionContext] 32: aastore [InstructionContext] 33: dup [InstructionContext] 34: iconst_1 [InstructionContext] 35: aload_2 [InstructionContext] 36: aastore [InstructionContext] 37: dup [InstructionContext] 38: iconst_2 [InstructionContext] 39: iload_3 [InstructionContext] 40: new 308 [InstructionContext] 43: dup_x1 [InstructionContext] 44: swap [InstructionContext] 45: invokespecial 651 [InstructionContext] 48: aastore [InstructionContext] 49: getstatic 653 [InstructionContext] 52: invokeinterface 54 [InstructionContext] 57: dup [InstructionContext] 58: ifnonnull -> 66 [InstructionContext] 66: checkcast 308 [InstructionContext] 69: invokevirtual 312 [InstructionContext] 72: goto -> 85 [InstructionContext] 85: invokestatic 1656 [InstructionContext]
So, there are two routes to instruction 85 that arrive with differing stacks.
The key thing to recognize is *how aspectj implements after advice*. We have put the code to call the advice in at instruction 85 - AND WE HAVE MODIFIED EVERY RETURN INSTRUCTION IN THE METHOD TO INSTEAD CALL THE ADVICE INSTRUCTIONS. This means where there used to be multiple 'escape routes' from the method, there is now *ONE* at the end of the advice. And you can see the calls at instruction 72 and instruction 82 that used to be 'ireturns' are now 'gotos' that jump to the advice. This exposes a stack management issue that was there all along. In the original code there were two returns out of the program and at each return the stack was different - verification doesn't check this.
Now, unfortunately the verifier only tells me one of the routes (DOH!) - what we actually see above is the route that results in a single 'int' on the stack. Let's take an alternative route and look at the stack:
0: aload_0 STACK = 'this' 1: getfield #38; //Field CGLIB$CALLBACK_0:Lnet/sf/cglib/proxy/MethodInterceptor; STACK = 'this.MethodInterceptor CGLIB$CALLBACK_0' 4: dup STACK = 'this.MethodInterceptor CGLIB$CALLBACK_0' 'this.MethodInterceptor CGLIB$CALLBACK_0' 5: ifnonnull 17 STACK = 'this.MethodInterceptor CGLIB$CALLBACK_0' 8: pop STACK = 9: aload_0 STACK = 'this' 10: invokestatic #42; //Method CGLIB$BIND_CALLBACKS:(Ljava/lang/Object;)V STACK = '' 13: aload_0 STACK = 'this' 14: getfield #38; //Field CGLIB$CALLBACK_0:Lnet/sf/cglib/proxy/MethodInterceptor; STACK = 'this.MethodInterceptor CGLIB$CALLBACK_0' 17: dup STACK = 'this.MethodInterceptor CGLIB$CALLBACK_0' 'this.MethodInterceptor CGLIB$CALLBACK_0' 18: ifnull 75 STACK = 'this.MethodInterceptor CGLIB$CALLBACK_0'
let's assume its null and jump to 75
75: aload_0 STACK = 'this.MethodInterceptor CGLIB$CALLBACK_0' 'this' 76: aload_1 STACK = 'this.MethodInterceptor CGLIB$CALLBACK_0' 'this' 'ProfileItem$ItemStatus' 77: aload_2 STACK = 'this.MethodInterceptor CGLIB$CALLBACK_0' 'this' 'ProfileItem$ItemStatus' 'ProfileItem$StatusReason' 78: iload_3 STACK = 'this.MethodInterceptor CGLIB$CALLBACK_0' 'this' 'ProfileItem$ItemStatus' 'ProfileItem$StatusReason' 'boolean' 79: invokespecial #646; //Method com/mprv/secsph/profile/domain/BaseParameterItem.changeItemMode:(Lcom/mprv/secsph/profile/domain/ProfileItem$ItemStatus;Lcom/mprv/secsph/profile/domain/ProfileItem$StatusReason;Z)Z STACK = 'this.MethodInterceptor CGLIB$CALLBACK_0' 'boolean' 82: goto 85
// BANG, route to 85 that leaves us with the additional MethodInterceptor on the stack.
What's missing? In the jump from 18 to 75, there is a missing 'pop' that would have cleared the stack. (like the pattern at instruction 5 and 8 - after a null check, you do a pop).
If I insert a 'pop' instruction at position 75 (before the aload_0) then the stack is emptied. We will then reach instruction 85 with the same stack regardless of the route taken.
I have hacked the CGLIB generated code and inserted the 'pop' at that position - after weaving, this results in a form of the code that verifies perfectly.
So ... it's a feature of the CGLIB generated code that it can't be woven by AspectJ after advice (or constructs that weave in a similar way, like cflow). I imagine javac and other bytecode producers never create code with differing stack heights when they return from a method. I'm not quite sure what to do now ... the original CGLIB code isn't wrong as it passes verification, it just doesn't lend itself to AspectJ weaving. It doesn't seem unreasonable for CGLIB to insert that pop to produce 'nice' bytecode. But, in the short term, I wondering how stable the pattern is for the generated method. Can I reliably insert the missing 'pop' under all circumstances... May be try posting to CGLIB forum? I have posted to the CGLIB mailing list.
My question for you is whether you really want/need to weave these proxies in the first place? I can imagine situations where it will give you unexpected/incorrect results. If you weave 'execution(* someMethod(..))' and there is a proxy created for the class containing 'someMethod' then your advice can run twice, once in the advised proxy and again if the proxy eventually calls the original method. It might be that you want to add an element to the aop.xml that causes it avoid weaving *anything* proxy like - does that sound reasonable? Bingo!!
It what I was going to ask from you anyway :-).
But the catch is: in the near future I'm planning some code generation with CGLIB ... But you are right ... it'll be VERY confusing when aspectj will weave'em.
You know ... for now it's best for me not to weave the generated code at all, as long as it's propose is creating a proxy. So may be this new element will do something like that:

The porpose of LTW for me was to save people's time by allowing'em to compile ONLY what they've changed using javac.
