Bug.WithOutStack: The file size of type pdf2 that engine smoke test generated is zero. fix the issue Verify this bug. closed!

Bug.Summery: JavaElement.getURLContents(...) leaves file open
Bug.WithStack:
I20051123
The AttachedJavadocTests sometimes fail because JavaElement.getURLContents(...) leaves a file open and the test cannot delete the project in the tearDownSuite() method because of that.
More specifcally URLConnection.getContentEncoding() opens a file stream on the doc.zip and never closes it. So this looks like a bug in the implementation of URLConnection.getContentEncoding(). I added a workaround in AbstractJavaModelTests.deleteResource(IResource) to force the GC to run so that the finalize method of the file input stream is run.
I also noticed that getContentEncoding() always return null for this test. If this call is not necessary, a fix would be to always use the default encoding.
Olivier, since this is your code, I'll let you decide. I suspected something like that. The problem is that this call is necessary to make sure that the stream is read using the right encoding. If we use the default encoding, it might work most of the time, but if the file specifies explicitely what encoding should be used, we will miss it. I disabled the caching in the URL connection to prevent such open streams, but it seems that this is not enough. I need to investigate if there is another way to retrieve the encoding in the file. I don't get the content encoding anymore. I use the default encoding specified as a parameter first. If null, I use the default encoding of the project and if this one is unsupported, I use the platform encoding. Fixed and released in HEAD. I'll monitor future builds to ensure the intermittent failure is gone. Verified for 3.2 M4 with build I20051213-0010 (In reply to Olivier Thomann from comment #3) > I don't get the content encoding anymore.
Note that this "fix" has been reverted with bug 122506, but the outdated comment on org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.JavaElement#getURLContents(..) stayed. Will remove the comment with fix for bug 450684.
Bug.WithOutStack:
I20051123
The AttachedJavadocTests sometimes fail because JavaElement.getURLContents(...) leaves a file open and the test cannot delete the project in the tearDownSuite() method because of that.
More specifcally URLConnection.getContentEncoding() opens a file stream on the doc.zip and never closes it. So this looks like a bug in the implementation of URLConnection.getContentEncoding(). I added a workaround in AbstractJavaModelTests.deleteResource(IResource) to force the GC to run so that the finalize method of the file input stream is run.
I also noticed that getContentEncoding() always return null for this test. If this call is not necessary, a fix would be to always use the default encoding.
Olivier, since this is your code, I'll let you decide. I suspected something like that. The problem is that this call is necessary to make sure that the stream is read using the right encoding. If we use the default encoding, it might work most of the time, but if the file specifies explicitely what encoding should be used, we will miss it. I disabled the caching in the URL connection to prevent such open streams, but it seems that this is not enough. I need to investigate if there is another way to retrieve the encoding in the file. I don't get the content encoding anymore. I use the default encoding specified as a parameter first. If null, I use the default encoding of the project and if this one is unsupported, I use the platform encoding. Fixed and released in HEAD. I'll monitor future builds to ensure the intermittent failure is gone. Verified for 3.2 M4 with build I20051213-0010 (In reply to Olivier Thomann from comment #3) > I don't get the content encoding anymore.
Note that this "fix" has been reverted with bug 122506, but the outdated comment on org.eclipse.jdt.internal.core.JavaElement#getURLContents(..) stayed. Will remove the comment with fix for bug 450684.

Bug.Summery: [Progress] java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: endRule without matching beginRule: R/
Bug.WithStack:
When trying to delete .sql file from the Package Explorer by right mouse click and selecting Delete, nothing happens. Then I press the Delete key and error message pop ups: endRule without matching beginRule: R/
I can not rename files in the Package Explorer either.
I also had some problems with the new version of the Colorer plug-in, could not use refactoring tools etc. for the .java files. I fixed it by changing the file association for .java files.

The refactoring wizard uses: manager.beginRule(ResourcesPlugin.getWorkspace().getRoot(), null); and finally manager.endRule(ResourcesPlugin.getWorkspace().getRoot());
see RefactoringWizardOpenOperation$1.run(RefactoringWizardOpenOperation.java:133)
What could be the problem is the NPE in org.eclipse.ui.internal.UILockListener.doPendingWork(UILockListener.java(Compiled
Moving to platform.ui It is impossible for an NPE to occur in UILockListener.doPendingWork... I think the NPE is occurring in some runnable, but this is being masked by the JIT (note the stack says it occurs in "compiled code"). We have had this reported before (bug 65724), but it is wrong.
The beginRule/endRule error may also be misleading. If someone else released that rule during the operation, this is the failure that would occur. Does this failure still occur without the "colorer" plugin installed? I suspect some refactoring participant is releasing a rule that it didn't acquire. Bug.Summery: [code formatter] ability to align arguments vertically in a row

Lines.Line: r.getLong( "CACHEINVALIDATION_ID" ),
r.getTimestamp( "STARTED" ),

Bug.WithStack:
Code Formatter ought to be able to align method argument vertically like this:
method("param1", 2, obj.three(), new Long(4)); This should already be doable. What are your code formatter settings? Line Wrapping > Function Calls > *: Wrap all element, except frist element if not neccessary and Indent on column. This formats as:
while( r.next() ) prioritizedIds.add( new CacheInvalidationServer( r.getLong( "PRIORITY" ), r.getLong( "CACHEINVALIDATION_ID" ), r .getTimestamp( "STARTED" ), r.getTimestamp( "FINISHED" ) ) );
and should
while( r.next() ) prioritizedIds.add( new CacheInvalidationServer( r.getLong( "PRIORITY" ), r.getLong( "CACHEINVALIDATION_ID" ), r.getTimestamp( "STARTED" ), r.getTimestamp( "FINISHED" ) ) );
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 59891 *** It was in fact more a duplicate of bug 264112, hence it's fixed since 3.6M5.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 264112 *** Verified for 3.6M7 using build I20100426-0852.

Bug.Summery: Workspace upgraded to M9, project type incorrectly detection due to .runtime existance
Bug.WithStack:
Bug report added in behalf of Russel Dodd which actually had the problem first hand, there are a number of NNTP ports on news.eclipse.org in eclipse.webtools newsgroup over the past 2 days.
I myself (Darryl) has also had these same problems a number of week ago, but was not paying too much attention as to why or what as I was more interested in getting my workspace/projects back into working order.
I loaded my workspace into I20041116xxxx which I had previously used with version 0.7.1 so my workspace was automatically upgraded.
However some of my J2EE Utility Jar (jst.utility 1.0) projects were not being detected as that project type by the J2EE / Server components.
In the Server property page I would get a "This project Can not be deployed to a server" and in the J2EE Dependancies -> Web Modules the project would not get listed as an allowable J2EE-dependant project.
I had to remove the .runtime file that existed in the J2EE utility JAR project toplevel directory, I believe this information is now stored as a project facet and does not actually need to exist in a utility project only a deployable dynamic web project.
I have other J2EE Utility projects that do have .runtime files in the toplevel project directory but Eclipse is able to correctly detect the project type of J2EE Utility Jar. Its it really confuses me why some projects .runtime causes a problem and in others it does not.
So althrough I have managed to manually fix my upgrade from 0.7.1 to M9 for my projects I am not sure what was actually broken or maybe broken in the auto-detection of project type.
Maybe someone reading this report might know or have an idea. I had the problems on my Windows XP machine. Can you please retest on the RC2 driver? This bug is being moved to the 'closed' state since it has been in the 'remind' state for a so long it is assume it is no longer a problem or otherwise not a useful bugzilla entry.
If this semi-automatic processing is in error, please re-open, or open another bug.
Reopening, in order to put into a valid closed state as remind is now deprecated, and closed, remind, does not make much sense. Resolving as won't fix, as these had previously been closed out, if this is incorrect, please provide more data and reopen.
Thanks, Re-closing appropriately with valid state.

After that, I did a new fresh install of the GTK version and did the same: installed VE only. Then I tried to create a visual class and BAM, it crashed right into my face.

Sorry the second post, I forgot to add that in Ubuntu 5.04 (Hoary) VE worked perfectly. I don't know what version of GTK2 this ubuntu came with, if anyone know please do post here ok? Hi Danilo, Ubuntu 5.10 has IPv6 enabled by default. VE shows the components you drop by talking to a remote VM using sockets. The problem is that VE cannot resolve the location of the VM because of IPv6. If you look at your /etc/hosts file, there should be an entry to resolve the host 'localhost' to the ip '127.0.0.1'. This line reads like: ---------------- 127.0.0.1 localhost.localdomain localhost mymachine ----------------
Please change the line so that the IP '127.0.0.1' resolves to 'localhost' first: ---------------- 127.0.0.1 localhost localhost.localdomain mymachine ----------------
And VE should work. Thanks. (In reply to comment #15) > Hi Danilo, Ubuntu 5.10 has IPv6 enabled by default. VE shows the components you > drop by talking to a remote VM using sockets. The problem is that VE cannot > resolve the location of the VM because of IPv6. If you look at your /etc/hosts > file, there should be an entry to resolve the host 'localhost' to the ip > '127.0.0.1'. This line reads like: > ---------------- > 127.0.0.1 localhost.localdomain localhost mymachine > ---------------- > > Please change the line so that the IP '127.0.0.1' resolves to 'localhost' > first: > ---------------- > 127.0.0.1 localhost localhost.localdomain mymachine > ---------------- > > And VE should work. > Thanks. >
I Sri.
I tried that, but it didn't work, Eclipse still crashes when I create a swing class with VE.
Besides, it works when I use the Motif version of Eclipse, it only crashes when I use the GTK version, so I don't think it have anything to do with IPv6.
And Ubuntu 5.04 had IPv6 enabled by default also but, as I said, VE worked in Ubuntu 5.04.
I really think its an issue related to the GTK used in Ubuntu 5.10.
Thanks anyway. Actually you must remove the localHost from the IPV6 line. It gets confused when localhost is on both. (In reply to comment #17) > Actually you must remove the localHost from the IPV6 line. It gets confused > when localhost is on both. >
Tried that also, and still it crashes. Are you guys using Ubuntu 5.10 and I'm the only one having problems?
Thanks. For me VE worked fine on Ubuntu 5.10 live CD. The only problem I had was with the ipV6 sockets, which was fixed once I made the changes mentioned on /etc/hosts. There was a message in the .log file saying that VE coulndt create sockets etc.
Since you dont have any of those problems, could you please mention which JRE you use for your IDE/projects? I dont think this is a GTK problem as the crash happens when you use only swing components too. It looks like the crash happens when you use any kind of widgets. 1 - It work for me when I use Motif Eclipse. 2 - Remember that Swing components still relies on heavy weight components when drawing windows. When it must draw title bars, maximize and minimize buttons, etc, it relies on heavy weight AWT components that access GTK to draw itself.

And Ubuntu 5.04 had IPv6 enabled by default also but, as I said, VE worked in Ubuntu 5.04.
I really think its an issue related to the GTK used in Ubuntu 5.10.
Thanks anyway. Actually you must remove the localHost from the IPV6 line. It gets confused when localhost is on both. (In reply to comment #17) > Actually you must remove the localHost from the IPV6 line. It gets confused > when localhost is on both. >
Tried that also, and still it crashes. Are you guys using Ubuntu 5.10 and I'm the only one having problems?
Thanks. For me VE worked fine on Ubuntu 5.10 live CD. The only problem I had was with the ipV6 sockets, which was fixed once I made the changes mentioned on /etc/hosts. There was a message in the .log file saying that VE coulndt create sockets etc.
Since you dont have any of those problems, could you please mention which JRE you use for your IDE/projects? I dont think this is a GTK problem as the crash happens when you use only swing components too. It looks like the crash happens when you use any kind of widgets. I'm using JDK5.0 both for running eclipse and for creating my projects. The IPv6 fix did'nt work for me. I still think its a GTK problem for two reasons:
1 - It work for me when I use Motif Eclipse. 2 - Remember that Swing components still relies on heavy weight components when drawing windows. When it must draw title bars, maximize and minimize buttons, etc, it relies on heavy weight AWT components that access GTK to draw itself.
Thanks Hello, I tried the motif version and when eclipse is loading I have this error message : "JVM terminated. exit code = 6....."
Any idea?? This fixed the crashing under my environment
https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=117898#c17 I have this same problem, has anyone found a solution for it? Same error, same configuration, etc.. and changing /etc/hosts didn't worked.
Moving to WONTFIX status since their isn't anything VE can do to fix this problem.

Bug.Summery: [ColorCellEditor] button is cropped
Bug.WithStack:
On the mac platform colorcelleditor buttons in tables are cropped and difficult to select. (win32: no problem) Created attachment 30550 Screenshot
See the attached screenshot for an example. I suspect that the Mac has a large margin around the button and that the colorcelleditor assumes that this isn't the case. Not sure there's much we can do about this.
